text: - Hello, my name is Rory Richardson.

I'm the Director of
Go-to-Market for Amazon Q Developer,
and we are at Amazon Generative AI Day

where we get to talk about
best practices and use cases
and how we're applying these technologies
to transform Amazon itself.

So today we're talking
to Vaughn Schermerhorn.
You want to introduce yourself?
- Hi. Yeah, thank you.
My name is Vaughn Schermerhorn.
I'm a Director here at Amazon.
I've been at Amazon for right around 14 years.

Done a lot of different
things in my time here.
And I think today we're going to spend

a lot of time talking
about portion of my job,
which is customer reviews.
- And customer reviews are critical
for the success of Amazon.com.
So first, let's level set.
Tell me how it was two years ago
and how we were handling customer reviews,

and then what projects we've
taken on to transform it.

- Sure, so what's what's really
great about customer reviews
and the work that we're doing right now,
I like to talk about it
as one of those overnight success stories
that's been years in the making.
We've spent a lot of time investing
in the science behind customer reviews.

And what I mean by that is
that like customer reviews,

like look, if you're
going to go buy something,

you're probably want to
ask someone who you know

and who knows you and
can make a recommendation

and help you kind of cut
through that clutter.
But not every purchase that we make
do we have someone like that in our lives.
And that's where customer reviews come in

because Amazon's not
telling you what to do,
the manufacturer, the vendor, whomever,
it's another customer who's like you,
who has a life experience
and a usage of that product like you.
And that experience

and trust has been critical
since the very beginning.
One of the issues though,
that we've seen for a long time,
but we've been able to address
over the last couple of years,

is the fact that oftentimes
we have too much.
And if you're looking at a product
that might have 10 or 15 reviews, okay.
we have some that have 300, 400,000,
not many, but they're there.

How could you possibly
search through all of that

and get the wisdom of
the crowd out of that?

And so what we've used with
science and generative AI
is to distill the wisdom of the crowd

into something that
customers can access easily,

understand easily, go as deep
or as shallow as they want to,
and still maintain that customer trust,
still provide that transparency,
still provide those guardrails.
So two years ago you would see
the top-ranked customer reviews
that we had on the detail page,
and you can still see them today.
But what you can see now

is a summarized paragraph
leveraging generative AI

that tells you what everyone
has said about this product
in a way that helps you make decisions.

And it leverages specific
aspects of the product

that are derived from
all of these reviews.

That you can then, if that's
the thing that interests you,
let's say you're buying a baby stroller,

there's something in there
about the weight of the stroller

and you're like, "That's
super important to me

because this is something I'm
going to lift off the ground

and put it in the back of
my car back and forth."
You can click on that aspect

and then see a summarization
that's specific to that aspect.

So we're really giving
customers the ability

to know as much or as
little as they want to
with as little work on their part.
- I mean, zooming out for just a second

and we'll get back to
the specific use case.

This feels like we are
democratizing analysis

on a scale that I didn't
even think was possible.

- Right, and well, it wasn't
just a couple of years ago,
and now it is.
And it's been an amazing partnership

with all of the teams within
AWS to be able to get here
to kind of describe what it is
that we wanted to deliver for customers,

to leverage not just some
of our generative AI tools,
but to better leverage SageMaker,

to better leverage other
tools within the AWS suite
to put our pipelines together in a way

that we can go from
non-generative AI science
smoothly into generative AI

to create a pipeline that
builds this tool for customers

that is cheap, flexible,
extensible worldwide,

almost no latency, the way
that we're building it.

And AWS has been our
partner in taking our vision

and making it into production
every step of the way.
- What was the hardest thing
that you had to take on in this project?

I mean, like-
- All of it.
Yeah.
- I mean, 'cause how long did it take you
from having a vision of

where the North Star
experience for customers,
where you wanted to go
to getting it actually in production?
- So believe it or not,

we were actually way faster
than I thought we could be

and that maybe a lot of other
people thought we could be.
We were able to leverage a body of work

and some scientific research
that we'd been doing for years

that helped us study the
language of customer reviews

and understand what customers
were talking about at scale.

And then, when generative
AI became more of a reality,

to layer that in, to be able
to provide the right insights
with the right CX for customers,

we were very, very excited and
pleased to be able to do it.

And it's funny how durable
that experience has been,
even as the company continues
to launch some amazing magic-like things

we're continuing to invest
in this particular feature
that isn't as open-ended

as many of the things that
Amazon and AWS are working on,
but it is very valuable for customers.
It's the, you know, I've been working
on some version of customer reviews
for seven, eight years now at this point.
And this is the first feature

that when I tell people
what I do, they're like,
"Oh, I use that."

And they're excited. I
can see it in their face.
And so, you know, at Amazon we measure-
- So you can tell your mom what you do?
- Exactly.
And she's like, "I use that.

I used that feature just
last week to buy this thing.
And it was great."
And that's been super satisfying
and super fun for not just me,

but the team and everybody
that's been involved.
- No, I get it.

I don't think my parents know
what my college degree is in.
So one of the things with customer reviews
that is absolute paramount is earns trust.

- Totally.
- Like,

if trust is broken in the
review process, if you feel

like it's a chatbot-
- That's right.
- You absolutely dismiss it.
So what are some of the guardrails
that you've had to think through
in order to ensure authenticity
and integrity in the customer reviews
so that the consumer can trust?

- We very much depend
on our annotation team
to help us go through cycles to make sure

that the aspects that we're
deriving from customer reviews,
as well as the way that we're summarizing
and the way that we're presenting them,

allow for the customer
voice to come through
as much as possible.

We always want this to
be about the customer,
both the shopping customer
and the ones that are writing the reviews.

We built the CX in a way that
allows you to click through
and see the reviews that the summarization
or the aspects are derived from,
so that if you want to check our work,
you can check our work.

And we've built tons of
guardrails and checks

and double checks both into
the code that we're using
and the pipeline that we're using,
but also with the instructions that we use
with our human annotation team
and the cycles of annotation that we do.

Because as you mentioned,
the most important thing

that we have and that
we absolutely cherish
when it comes to customer reviews
is the trust of our customers.

If they can't trust us,
we don't have anything.
And so that's been something

that's been baked into our
experience from day one.
- So what's next with,
and like where's your North Star?

What is the art of the possible
of where you can take this?
- That we have so many,
so many hopes and dreams in this space,
but ultimately what it comes back to
is our goal has been for years
and will remain helping customer,
and this is a little bit of Amazon speak,

but helping customers make
unregretted purchasing decisions.

Really giving them the
tools and the information
to feel confident in the purchase
and the choice that they're making.

And there's a lot of
different ways to solve that,

and we're solving it from
one particular angle.
But as we look at this,

we launched in the US and
we launched in English,

and then we expanded to other
marketplaces in English.

And we've just now within
the last couple months,
started to launch in European countries
and a couple of other marketplaces
where English is not the primary language.

So into German, into
French, and to Spanish.
Amazon is a very big company
and we have shopping opportunities
in lots of different countries,
in lots of different languages.

So we are definitely in the
process of going worldwide.

We're playing with multilingual
and cross-lingual models.
We see huge opportunities there.

I mean, the science is
just changing so fast
when it comes to human communication.
We're super excited in that space.

- And personalization.
- And personalization.

- I mean, those markets-
- I would love-
- would make different type of decisions

with different priorities.
- They do.
And the reviews will reflect that.

Someday, I would love to
present to you customer reviews

that are important to
you and maybe only you
in terms of like what's important to Rory
and her decision-making process

and the things that she
wants to know about a review,
and take that wisdom of the crowd
and make it personalized and individual.
- Like if I was buying a piece of clothing
and maybe the reviews from 5'3" women

would be of a higher
priority to someone like me.

- Height, weight, size,
price point, like quality.
I'm going to hazard a guess
that my 15-year-old who loves clothing
has a very different price point
and taste in clothes than you do.
And right now, as you're looking through,

we can't help you as much
as I would like to be able
to do when it comes to those things.

So, you know, I'm all about
listening to our customers
as much as possible

and giving that information
back to other customers
in a way that is as easy for them to use

to make the perfect
shopping decision for them

as fast as possible and
as easy as possible.
- How are you measuring the ROI
or the impact of this investment?
You know, because a lot of times

when your a company, you
have to invest in things
that you know it's the right thing.
But you're not exactly sure
how you're going to measure the ROI.
And of course we measure everything here.

- We do.
- So how do we see
that impacting, I don't know,
consumers' purchasing decisions?
- Well, we look at a lot of things,

and actually we're pretty
lucky with this feature

that a lot of the metrics that
we measure within the store

were positively impacted by
this feature right off the bat.
Customers told us almost from day one,
"I love this, this is adding value.
More of this, please."
And we saw it not only in the results
that we got when we would test things A-B
against each other, but we would see it

in where customers were
spending their time.

Meaning we saw that customers
were spending less time
having to read through as many reviews.
And a lot of times people would say like,
"Oh, people are using my feature less.
That means this isn't good."
But in my case, if people are able

to make that decision-
- Right, you can measure

how fast to get to a decision.
- faster and easier.
That's right. That's right.
- Oh, that's an interesting metric.

I didn't consider that.
- And we can see

how much they're interacting
with the summary,

how much they're clicking
through to explore more,
how often they're doing that,
when the item may costs more versus less,
or they're making a tougher decision-
- Yeah, the heuretics are fascinating.
- between a bunch of different things.
And it gives us insight into some things

that we want to be able
to do in the future.

- It gets me thinking about
discoverability as well.

I mean like what if I could
search just on customer reviews
to get a recommendation
and not necessarily the product name?

- Well, so here's an
example I like to use a lot.
Customers will tell you if they think,
for example, this chair,
is this chair comfortable?
I mean, you could ask the manufacturer,

I think they're probably
going to tell you "yes."
But what does that really matter?

- It doesn't really help.
- You know what I mean?
Or how do you compare it.

But if a thousand customers
have bought this chair

and they overwhelmingly
say that it's comfy,
we can put that information

into other places within
the shopping experience

so that if you were to then
search for a comfy chair,
this is it.
It's been approved by customers.

They're saying it's comfortable
and you can trust them
and find it in our store through that way.

- Oh, that's fascinating.
- Yeah.
